{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3357325,"name":"Kevin Beshears","username":"BeaverDuck","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/beaverduck/{size}/168119_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-10T06:28:13.805Z","cooked":"

Hello Everyone,

Long time thread reader, first time thread creator.

The title is not bait.

I have been thinking about doing this since I graduated in 2020. I have finally sat down and done some work for it.

I will be documenting and posting updates and the documentation here if anyone would like to follow this project. Currently I only plan to design the gearbox, but if there is enough traction then I will look into building and testing it.

Here is a sneak peak at what I roughed out in today in about 4 hours.

IsometricImage847×628 162 KB

If anyone has experience with designing one of these and would like to tell me to stop or would like to give me some tips. Please feel free to give me advice.

AFAIK, 217 was the first to use a CVT in FRC, all the way back in 2002. Unfortunately the whitepapers have been lost to the depths of the internet.

Much more recently, 1640 made a CVT swerve.

1640 Sab-BOT-age 2020 CVT Swerve Module Reveal Robot Showcase
1640, Sab-BOT-age, is proud to present our 2020 CVT Swerve Module. [render1] Our 2017-2019 CVT swerve was designed to add CVT functionality on top of our standard swerve module, which has only seen iterative changes since its inception in 2010. While this provided us a lot of success and the base swerve module was robust, proven, and reliable, it provided for a suboptimal implementation of CVT. Over the last 2 years, we have spent countless hours redesigning our swerve module from the ground …
","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-04-10T06:57:32.142Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":642,"readers_count":641,"score":198.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":462052,"topic_slug":"frc-sized-cvt-offseason-project","display_username":"Sean Lavery","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/1640-sab-bot-age-2020-cvt-swerve-module-reveal/368492","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"1640 Sab-BOT-age 2020 CVT Swerve Module Reveal","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":2514,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 1712"},"post_url":"/t/frc-sized-cvt-offseason-project/462052/2","custom_user_title":"FRC 1712","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3357645,"name":"Art Dutra IV","username":"artdutra04","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/artdutra04/{size}/65178_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-10T16:01:08.461Z","cooked":"
Lil_Lavery:

Unfortunately the whitepapers have been lost to the depths of the internet.

The ZIP download link here still works for the 2002 Crazy Chicken Transmission (CCT) FRC217 white paper + Solidworks CAD models: Thunder Chicken CCT

AFAIK, FRC 190 also had a CVT transmission in I believe 2002, that I’m struggling to find photos / info on at the moment. I recall seeing it in in their workshop way back when I helped mentor for them in 2008. It relied in the high coefficient of friction (aka galling) nature of aluminum on aluminum for torque transfer between concave “t-shaped concave drums” that a rotating disc would rotate along to make contact with different effective diameters between the two “t-shaped concave drums” to achieve different gear ratios.

Gotta add all the keywords in so hopefully future searches can find it easier.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-04-10T16:01:08.461Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":527,"readers_count":526,"score":180.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":462052,"topic_slug":"frc-sized-cvt-offseason-project","display_username":"Art Dutra IV","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/thunder-chicken-cct/39311","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Thunder Chicken CCT","clicks":23}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":4740,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Alumni FRC228"},"post_url":"/t/frc-sized-cvt-offseason-project/462052/3","custom_user_title":"Alumni FRC228","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3357673,"name":"RogerR","username":"RogerR","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rogerr/{size}/605_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-10T16:18:57.991Z","cooked":"

I won’t go into the long explanation here (I’ll link to it, though), but it’s worth noting that 217’s CCT (Crazy Chicken Transmission) is not truly a CVT by most common definitions.

For those unfamiliar, usually a CVT has the ability to vary the effective reduction continuously independent of the motor inputs or outputs (so power in and power out remain similar, and just trade torque for RPM or vice versa). The dual input planetary can potentially have two “gears” (one with high torque, the other with high RPM), but in between these extremes, you would see the input and output power dip, as one motor slows, stops, and the reverses direction.

See the below link for a much better explanation (and some good points on potential improvements, benefits, warnings, etc.) from @Paul_Copioli who was pretty involved in the development:

Post on CCT

artdutra04:

AFAIK, FRC 190 also had a CVT transmission in I believe 2002, that I’m struggling to find photos / info on at the moment. I recall seeing it in in their workshop way back when I helped mentor for them in 2008. It relied in the high coefficient of friction (aka galling) nature of aluminum on aluminum for torque transfer between concave “t-shaped concave drums” that a rotating disc would rotate along to make contact with different effective diameters between the two “t-shaped concave drums” to achieve different gear ratios.

If that was confusing, here’s a better image to help illustrate this concept:

It’s referred to as a Torodial CVT, and the image is from one used in a Nissan Cedric Y34.

What is the goal of the CVT (i.e. what is an example mechanism it would br used for if any)?

Are you planning on designing a custom CVT mechanism or using a COTS one?

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-04-10T16:55:11.338Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":364,"readers_count":363,"score":92.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":462052,"topic_slug":"frc-sized-cvt-offseason-project","display_username":"Max Morehead","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53784,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/frc-sized-cvt-offseason-project/462052/6","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3357806,"name":"Doug Frisk","username":"Doug_Frisk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/doug_frisk/{size}/125193_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-10T17:44:40.358Z","cooked":"

Indeed, CVTs are interesting technologically, and for gasoline or diesel engines they address a specific issue, the torque/efficiency band of the engine is narrow so they allow an engine to operate in its most efficient RPM band. The losses generated by the CVT itself are overcome by the efficiency gained by running the engine at an optimal RPM.

That tradeoff doesn’t exist with electric motors, there really isn’t any efficiency to be gained that would offset the losses in the CVT. That’s why EVs generally have a single speed transmission with the exception of the Porsche Taycan and its Audi equivalent which opt for a two speed gearbox but only on the rear axle.

Fun project though, I’m interested to see how it works out.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-04-10T17:44:40.358Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":330,"readers_count":329,"score":81.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":462052,"topic_slug":"frc-sized-cvt-offseason-project","display_username":"Doug Frisk","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":53784,"username":"Max_Morehead","name":"Max Morehead","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/max_morehead/{size}/231937_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22789,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"The one with the practice field, Duluth RPC"},"post_url":"/t/frc-sized-cvt-offseason-project/462052/7","custom_user_title":"The one with the practice field, Duluth RPC","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3357865,"name":"Ben Bernard (He/Him)","username":"BenBernard","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/benbernard/{size}/8721_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-10T18:09:30.743Z","cooked":"

5687 did a CVT in 2016. I don’t know if we still have the CAD available from that far back, but if you’re interested I can ask our CAD folks to take a look.
